title: External tool telnet
author: LIyoai
body_snippet:
<!--
Only file GitHub issues for bugs and feature requests.  All other topics will be closed.

Before opening an issue, please search for a duplicate or closed issue.
Please provide as much detail as possible for us to fix your issue.
-->

<!-- Bug -->
Telnet as external tool is not working/found.
How to reproduce:
Start cmd through external tools
Go to c:\windows\system32
dir telnet.exe -> file not found.

Start a cmd out of windows you will find the file.

I guess this is becau...

iterations.description: Launching external tools via `%SystemRoot%\System32` from a 32-bit mRemoteNG process is WoW64-redirected to 32-bit binaries, which breaks expected telnet/PowerShell behavior on 64-bit Windows.

comments.author: sparerd
comments.snippet: I'm not sure what we can do to help here - this sounds like more of a system issue.

comments.author: LIyoai
comments.snippet:
Maybe a 64bit build?
But I have a workaround I use putty instead. So if you want close the ticket.

comments.author: sparerd
comments.snippet: We are investigating x64 builds, but that will probably be a little ways off. I thought we had an issue logged for it, but I couldn't find it. Created one now for tracking: #915

comments.author: kmscode
comments.snippet:
Looks like there is a way to do this, but it's a bit hacky:
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/2003573/how-to-start-a-64-bit-process-from-a-32-bit-process

Best to focus on 64 bit builds...

comments.author: LIyoai
domoaligato
comments.snippet: I have the same issue calling powershell to call quser or logoff. I have to call the x86 powershell and a lot of cmdlets are not available with it now.

notes:
AI triage (codex): Launching external tools via `%SystemRoot%\System32` from a 32-bit mRemoteNG process is WoW64-redirected to 32-bit binaries, which breaks expected telnet/PowerShell behavior on 64-bit Windows.
Approach: Add path normalization for external tools so `System32` can resolve to `Sysnative` when needed on 64-bit OS, with fallback and a small regression test.
